contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} '''Ye''' or '''Yecheng''' ({{zh|t=鄴城|s=邺城|p=Yèchéng|w=Yeh<sup>4</sup>-ch'eng<sup>2</sup>}}) was an ancient Chinese city located in what is now [[Linzhang]] County, [[Handan]], [[Hebei]] province and neighbouring [[Anyang]], [[Henan]] province. Ye was first built in the [[Spring and Autumn Period]] by [[Duke Huan of Qi]], and by the time of the [[Warring States Period]] the city belonged to the state of [[Wei (state)|Wei]]. Ye was a political and economic center of China during the [[Three Kingdoms Period]] and [[Northern Dynasties]]. It served as the military headquarters of the warlords [[Yuan Shao]] and [[Cao Cao]] in the last years of the [[Han Dynasty|Eastern Han Dynasty]] and later as the capital of the [[Eastern Wei Dynasty]] and [[Northern Qi Dynasty]]. The city was razed to the ground in 580, after [[Yang Jian]], founder of the [[Sui Dynasty]], defeated a resistance force led by [[Yuchi Jiong]], which used Ye as a base of operations. Extensive excavations of the city have been made in recent years, allowing Chinese historians to make detailed plans of the site. In 2012, archaeologists unearthed nearly 3,000 [[Buddha]] statues during a dig outside of Ye.
